chapter.title: Presentation accommodations provide access to content through alternative methods
chapter.content:
In this topic, we will take a closer look at presentation accommodations, which provide individuals access to content by alternative means. These alternatives include:

  • reading aloud, which may involve the use of a screen reader or a human reader;
  • alternative media, which includes the use of e-Text and audio books;
  • language structures, which include simplified syntax and plain English; and
  • font format, which include the use of large print or different font colors. 

For the majority of individuals with learning disabilities, read-alouds, or the oral presentation of print materials, are the most frequent accommodation requests.

For example, adult basic education learners with approved documentation can request GED test presentation accommodations in various formats including: Braille, audio format, large print, straight edge guide to facilitate reading, and colored overlays. Note that it is generally acknowledged that the use of colored overlays has no empirical research base (Ritchie et al., 2011; Denton & Meindl, 2015).

More Information

The GED Testing Service considers test accommodations on a case-by-case basis. Documentation guidelines for learning and cognitive disorders, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, psychological and psychiatric disorders, and physical disabilities and chronic health conditions are available on the GED Testing Service website.

chapter.title: Presentation accommodation resources
chapter.content: There are several types of resources students can access to assist their learning experience. These include electronic and audio alternative media. Electronic alternative media offers resources to augment reading experiences for students. Resources include Bookshare.org, an ebook library supported by the U.S. Department of Education, Office of Special Education Programs. U.S. students with a qualifying print disability may join Bookshare for free.

chapter.title: Does Billy qualify for accommodations?
chapter.content:
Let's take a look at another scenario of a student who may need accommodations to achieve optimal performance in a learning environment. 

Read Billy’s story, then determine whether he qualifies for accommodations.

Billy

Billy, a nineteen-year-old European American, comes from a rural farming community where he was identified as demonstrating LD in first grade. His reading decoding and comprehension skills have continued to be a critical area of underachievement for him throughout his elementary and secondary schooling. Unfortunately, Billy was unable to pass the  state language arts tests, so he dropped out of school.

Billy would like to attend a technical college, but he needs the GED to be accepted into the institution. Therefore, he is taking some ABE classes to help him prepare for taking the GED examination. He does not have documentation for GED testing accommodations.

Based on the information provided, does Billy qualify for GED accommodations?

  1. Yes
  2. No

When you have decided on your answer, click the forward arrow for the correct answer and the next question.

chapter.title: Qualification
chapter.content:
Billy does not qualify because he does not have recent documentation.

chapter.title: Basis for accommodations
chapter.content:
Billy may need accommodations based on a clinician assessment, lagging reading and decoding skills, and the instructor’s best judgment.

chapter.title: More accommodations
chapter.content:
The correct answer is d: all of the above. Based on the information provided, appropriate reading accommodations may include extra time for instructional and testing situations, text-to-speech software, and scheduled breaks. 

Billy

Billy, a nineteen-year-old European American, comes from a rural farming community where he was identified as demonstrating LD in first grade. His reading decoding and comprehension skills have continued to be a critical area of underachievement for him throughout his elementary and secondary schooling. Unfortunately, Billy was unable to pass his high school graduation reading and writing tests, so he dropped out of school.

Billy would like to attend a technical college, but he needs the GED to be accepted into the institution. Therefore, he is taking some ABE classes to help him prepare for taking the GED examination. He does not have documentation for GED testing accommodations.

Due to Billy's significant deficits with reading decoding and reading comprehension, accommodations specific to print access are critical for him. Researchers have provided a great deal of empirical evidence for the critical role reading fluency plays in high speed word recognition and comprehension of text (National Reading Panel, 2000). Therefore, like Hamid, Billy should be provided the accommodation of extra time on literacy tasks due to his reading decoding and comprehension deficits that interfere with reading fluency.

In addition, various new technologies are being used to accommodate the learning and work environments for adolescents and adults with LD. For Billy, alternative media such as electronic text (e-Text) and the software to access e-Text (text-to-speech) are critical tools for acquiring print. Text-to-speech software can enable the reading of a computer display, or it may simply be used to augment the reading of text message.

Vocational rehabilitation services assisted Billy in obtaining an evaluation to have the documentation required for receiving accommodations on the GED test and for reading accommodations in the classroom.
